accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: Joel de la Fuente. as Inspector Kido
Macall Gordon. as Anne Crain Walker
Jason Riki Kosuge. as Japanese Father
Andy Yu. as Japanese Imperial Army Soldier

textMap.PRIMARY: 5. The Crown Prince is rushed to the hospital
8. The Crown Princess waits for an update on the Prince
12. Tagomi makes plans to get Wegener out of the Pacific States
13. Frank attempts to stay low-key at work
14. Inspector Kido stakes his life on finding the shooter
15. Juliana is banned from training in the dojo
19. Smith deems Joe's mission a failure
20. Bill holds a memorial service for his family
22. The memorial service for Laura, Emily, John continues
23. Tagomi inquires about the foreign passports
24. Wegener attempts to leave the Pacific States
25. Juliana looks for a job at the Japanese Embassy

accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: Frank Frink. acted by Rupert Evans
Nobusuke Tagomi. acted by Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa
Rudolph Wegener. acted by Carsten Norgaard
Inspector Kido. acted by Joel de la Fuente
Ed McCarthy. acted by DJ Qualls
Juliana Crain. acted by Alexa Davalos
Arnold Walker. acted by Daniel Roebuck
Joe Blake. acted by Luke Kleintank
Harlan Wyndam-Matson. acted by Jack Kehler
Sergeant Yoshida. acted by Lee Shorten
Lawrence Klemm. acted by Steve Byers
John Smith. acted by Rufus Sewell

textMap.PRIMARY: In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," in addition to the Kempeitai, other protective forces present for the Crown Prince's speech are: the Imperial Guard, the Japanese Imperial Navy, and the Royal Imperial Guard who are uniform-less men in black double-breasted jackets and red hats.
Upwards of 300 background actors were utilized during the filming of the Crown Prince's speech.
The design of the Crown Princess' kimono is a nod to the famous pink suit Jackie Onassis wore the day John F. Kennedy was assassinated.

"The Man in the High Castle's" production design team imagined Hitler would use younger images of himself in propaganda material and billboards to inject a sense amongst his people that the Reich still has the same power and vigor it had during the war.
The production design of Smith's office represents the Nazi's post-war advancement in architecture by infusing mid-century brutalism with its use of exposed concrete.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the conquering Japanese are big fans of traditional 'Americana' and avidly collect artifacts of an idealized American past. Some of the most popular artifacts were those from the fabled 'Wild West', which has led to new industries arising to supply collectors. Frank's factory specializes in producing old revolvers and does so quite openly, which is a notable departure from "The Man in the High Castle" novel, where such industry was considered illegal.
Aikido is often translated as "the way of harmonious spirit," so maintaining harmony and order within the dojo is important in its teaching process.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Japanese Pacific States work with a three tier system of militia. On the top tier are Kempeitai Officers (like Sergeant Yoshida), the middle tier consists of Kempeitai Police (lower ranking officers), and the bottom tier are the Imperial Soldiers. The Kempeitai uniform is a more formal look in an olive tone, whereas the soldiers' uniforms are tan.
The Twin Peaks are two hills with an elevation of about 925 feet near the geographic center of San Francisco, CA. Except for Mount Davidson, they are the highest points in the city.

Yosemite National Park is located in Northern California and covers nearly 1,200 square miles. Set in the High Sierra mountains, Yosemite is known for its natural beauty, granite cliffs, vast meadows, waterfalls, clear streams, and giant sequoias.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," civil liberties barely exist in the totalitarian Pacific States. Citizens may be questioned without apparent cause, and even tortured or killed, with no legal recourse. Much like their Nazi counterparts, the Kempeitai operate with near impunity and may use whatever method of persuasion they see fit in order to extract information from suspects and witnesses.

During WWII, resistance movements (sometimes known as 'The Underground') operated in all of the occupied territories. The methods used to resist Axis occupation varied from disinformation, propaganda, hiding crashed pilots, and even taking up arms.
Nippon' is one of the Japanese words used for 'Japan'. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," 'Pons' is a derogatory short-hand for the Japanese.

The statue placed behind Smith represents the Reich's approval of classical Greek and Roman art. Hitler made it clear that modern art had no place in the Reich. When Hitler took over as Chancellor he banned and removed art deemed as degenerate or decadent. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," John Smith would place favorable art in his office to show his views are aligned with those of the Reich.

VA Day, or Victory in America Day, was created for "The Man in the High Castle," based on the real life VE Day (Victory in Europe Day, 8th May 1945) and VJ Day (Victory in Japan Day, 15th August 1945), marking the end of hostilities in Europe and Japan respectively. In reality, on VE Day over 1 million people celebrated on the streets of London and crowds amassed outside Buckingham Palace to celebrate, allowing Princess Elizabeth (the future Queen) and her sister Princess Margaret to celebrate among them incognito. In New York, the jubilation on the streets was very colorful, as garment factories threw their ribbons and silks from the windows in celebration and ships in the river blasted their sirens.
In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," this church once belonged to the Episcopalian faith but was converted to a hybrid of the Buddhist and Shinto religion.

The French Resistance was the term used to describe the various resistance cells that formed when the Nazis occupied France. While some took a violent approach, others used non-violent methods of resistance like producing underground newspapers and literature. Another non-violent act of resistance they carried out was to salvage art and literature that was considered 'degenerate,' which would have otherwise been destroyed by the Third Reich.

Even until relatively recently, women in Japan often only had a few working years, between the end of their education and marriage. Before the 1970s it was legal for companies to force women into retirement upon marriage. Women's peak working years were therefore 20-24, and, sometimes again from 35-50 as part-time workers, which protected the men within their permanent full time roles. Women who reached their late 20's, early 30's and remained unmarried were often the source of ridicule and gossip.

"L'Chaim" is a Hebrew saying which literally means 'to life', commonly used to make toasts. In "The Man in the High Castle," the Nazis have prioritized the eradication of the Jewish race, so using sayings like this in public is not only illegal, but highly dangerous.
A diplomatic ticket could be specially requested by government ministers to allow travel out of restricted areas. Tickets could be swiftly granted through the embassy.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Japanese Authority Building houses all government ministries in the Japanese Pacific States. It is casually referred to by the occupied population as the Nippon Building.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," fashion is still heavily influenced by the 1950's. Gloves were a common element of attire during that era and here they represent propriety, correctness, and modesty.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," in addition to the Kempeitai, other protective forces present for the Crown Prince's speech are: the Imperial Guard, the Japanese Imperial Navy, and the Royal Imperial Guard who are uniform-less men in black double-breasted jackets and red hats.
